 The bank teller and her husband, James, a plumber, met with a broker who said he would guarantee the rate for five years and then talked to other companies which couldn't match it.
 
 Things progressed smoothly with their $275,000 adjustable rate mortgage until the rate began to climb -- it's now 6.25 percent -- despite what they had been told. Today, they are facing a refinancing penalty and are unable to financially help a son who wants to attend a trade school.

 Can you say "retarded monkeys"? 
 
 I generally do not feel sorry for people who make stupid decisions, especially when the information is out in the public domain if they would just LOOK to make decisions that are NOT completely idiotic. 
 
 Yesterday I got a report back that I comissioned regarding probable real estate futures. The results were, in short, horrifying. Mos tprobably scenario is a 50% decline in new home construction by the end of next year. This would result in an overall GDP loss of 1.75% (just the lost construction). The flow through multiplier on that is 4.5-4.75 percent. Brutal. 
 
 Additionally, according to my numbers, roughly 9 trillion dollars in real estate "wealth" will vanish between January and decemebr of next year, with another 3.5 trillion vanishing between january and may of 2007. 
 
 With mortgage defaults running between 35 and 38% (which is actually lower than the previous numbers I have seen), there is no bottom to the market as people find that even their fixed rate mortgages include provisions in the event that the value of their property falls below the balance due ont he mortgage (this will be a problem for roughly 54% of current mortgage holders)
 
 Historic data shows very clearly that the idea that this will be confined to isolated regions is preposterous. Historically, large real estate corrections tend to be nationwide, though they hit harder in some regions than others. 
 
 The only real uncertainty left seems to be exactly how bad it will be, since 80% of our GDP is consumer spending, and a fall in the housing market will lead to significant job loss, which will facilitate a further fall in the market. An ugly self perpetuating cycle. 
 
 I actually am starting to feel sorry for folks like those highlighted in the article. Sure, they did something that was incredibly stupid. At the same time, I think there was almost a conspiracy (not quite, but almost) among public figures to ensure that people remained pacified and kept spending. That lost real estate wealth will bcoming directly out of the pockets of middle class (soon to be lower class) America.
